title: 109_s1539
content: The "Adoption Equality Act of 2005" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section of the Act is also included. The Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1997 prioritizes a child's health and safety, aiming to provide each child with a permanent home. Despite incentives for adoptions, many children in foster care still await adoption, especially older children with special needs. 118,000 children in foster care with adoption as their permanency goal are in need of Federal financial assistance and support due to special needs resulting from past abuse and neglect. SEC. 3. PROMOTION OF ADOPTION OF CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS. Section 473(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include criteria for a child to meet requirements for placement in the care of a public or licensed private agency for safety or welfare reasons. The Social Security Act is amended to include criteria for a child to meet requirements for placement in the care of a public or licensed private agency for safety or welfare reasons, including eligibility for supplemental security income benefits and special needs determination by the State. The Social Security Act is amended to include criteria for a child to meet requirements for placement in the care of a public or licensed private agency for safety or welfare reasons, including eligibility for supplemental security income benefits and special needs determination by the State. A child with special needs shall be considered by the State, along with the circumstances of the adopting parents, in determining adoption assistance payments. Non-US citizen children meeting certain criteria will be treated as meeting requirements for adoption assistance payments. The Families Act of 1997 allows for children who are available for adoption due to dissolved prior adoptions or parental rights termination to meet requirements for adoption assistance. An exception states that no payment may be made to parents for children with special needs who are not US citizens and were adopted outside the US. The Families Act of 1997 allows for adoption assistance for children with special needs. Payments are prohibited for non-US citizen children adopted outside the US, who are later placed in foster care after a failed adoption. States must use savings from reduced expenditures on adoption assistance for other purposes. The Adoption Equality Act of 2005 allows for the provision of services to children or families under this part or part B. Section 473(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to define a child with special needs as one who cannot be returned to their parents' home or meets medical/disability requirements for supplemental security income benefits. The Adoption Equality Act of 2005 defines a child with special needs as one who meets medical or disability requirements for supplemental security income benefits and cannot be placed with adoptive parents without adoption assistance and medical assistance. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on October 1, 2005.
